Yes, streaming services like Netflix and Hulu have become increasingly important for film distribution in recent years, and this trend is likely to continue. Streaming services offer a wider reach and access to a larger audience than traditional theaters, and they allow viewers to watch films at their own pace and on their own schedules. 

Streaming services have also become a popular option for independent filmmakers and production companies like Blumhouse Productions, who may find it challenging to secure theatrical releases for their films. By partnering with streaming services, filmmakers can reach a wider audience and generate buzz for their films without the need for a traditional theatrical release. 

However, it's important to note that traditional theaters are still a crucial part of the film distribution landscape, especially for blockbuster films or movies with wider commercial appeal. Many filmmakers and distributors see theatrical releases as a way to create buzz and build hype around their films, which can translate into higher revenues for both theater owners and production companies. 

Ultimately, the distribution strategy for each film will depend on a variety of factors, including the genre, target audience, and budget, among others. But there's no question that streaming services like Netflix and Hulu have become an important and growing distribution channel for film content in recent years.
